concepts.title: FSA Framework
concepts.desc: 1) State purpose/context, 2) Collect data, 3) Process data, 4) Analyze/interpret, 5) Develop conclusions, 6) Follow-up.

concepts.title: Three Main Statements
concepts.desc: Income statement (performance), Balance sheet (position), Cash flow statement (cash generation). Plus: Statement of changes in equity.

concepts.title: IFRS vs US GAAP
concepts.desc: IFRS: principles-based, used globally in 140+ countries. US GAAP: rules-based, used in US. Convergence ongoing but differences remain.

concepts.title: Auditor's Report
concepts.desc: Unqualified (clean), Qualified (except for), Adverse (material misstatements), Disclaimer (insufficient evidence).

concepts.title: Management Discussion & Analysis
concepts.desc: MD&A provides management's perspective on financial results, trends, risks, and forward-looking information.

concepts.title: Notes to Financial Statements
concepts.desc: Accounting policies, detail behind line items, contingent liabilities, segment reporting. Critical for analysis.

decisions.question: IFRS vs US GAAP key differences to watch?
use: Inventory: IFRS prohibits LIFO; US GAAP allows LIFO
Development costs: IFRS can capitalize; US GAAP expenses
Impairment: IFRS allows reversal for most assets; US GAAP does not
avoid: Assuming IFRS and GAAP are identical â€” material differences exist

pitfalls: An unqualified opinion does NOT mean the company is healthy â€” it means statements fairly present per standards
Off-balance-sheet items can be significant â€” read the notes carefully
Going concern qualification in audit report is a major red flag

questions.question: Under IFRS, which inventory method is NOT permitted?
questions.explanation: IFRS prohibits LIFO (Last In, First Out). US GAAP allows LIFO, FIFO, and weighted average.

questions.question: A qualified audit opinion means:
options: The financial statements are materially misstated throughout
The statements are fair except for a specific issue
The auditor could not obtain sufficient evidence
The statements are presented fairly in all respects
questions.explanation: Qualified = "except for" â€” fair presentation overall but with a specific deviation or limitation.

questions.question: The first step in the financial statement analysis framework is to:
options: State the purpose and context of the analysis
questions.explanation: Always start by clarifying why you're doing the analysis and what questions you need to answer.

concepts.title: Revenue Recognition
concepts.desc: IFRS 15 / ASC 606: 5-step model. Recognize when performance obligation satisfied and control transfers to customer.

concepts.title: Expense Recognition (Matching)
concepts.desc: Expenses matched to the revenues they help generate. Period costs expensed immediately; product costs match to sales.

concepts.title: Capitalization vs Expensing
concepts.desc: Capitalizing: asset on BS, depreciated over time (higher initial income). Expensing: immediate IS charge (lower initial income).

concepts.title: Basic EPS
concepts.desc: Net income attributable to common / Weighted average common shares outstanding. Measures profit per share for common shareholders.

concepts.title: Diluted EPS
concepts.desc: Assumes all dilutive securities (options, convertibles) are converted. Always â‰¤ Basic EPS. Treasury stock method for options.

concepts.title: Common-Size Income Statement
concepts.desc: Express each line as % of revenue. Enables comparison across companies of different sizes and over time.

formulas.name: Basic EPS
formulas.formula: Basic EPS = (Net Income - Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Avg Common Shares

formulas.name: Diluted EPS (Convertible Bonds)
formulas.formula: Diluted EPS = (NI - PD + InterestÃ—(1-t)) / (WACS + New shares from conversion)
formulas.where: If-converted method: add back interest, add converted shares

formulas.name: Diluted EPS (Options)
formulas.formula: Treasury Stock Method: New shares = Options exercised - Shares repurchased with proceeds
formulas.where: Net new shares = N - (NÃ—Exercise Price / Market Price)

formulas.name: Gross Profit Margin
formulas.formula: GPM = (Revenue - COGS) / Revenue

formulas.name: Operating Margin
formulas.formula: Op Margin = Operating Income / Revenue
formulas.where: Includes SG&A and other operating expenses

formulas.name: Net Profit Margin
formulas.formula: Net Margin = Net Income / Revenue

decisions.question: Capitalize or Expense?
use: Capitalize: future economic benefit expected (>1 year), cost reliably measurable
Expense: no future benefit, or benefit is uncertain
avoid: Aggressive capitalization to inflate current profits â€” a red flag for earnings quality

pitfalls: Capitalizing costs inflates current income but reduces future income (depreciation/amortization)
Diluted EPS: only include securities that are DILUTIVE (reduce EPS). Anti-dilutive items are excluded.
Revenue recognition timing differs between point-in-time and over-time â€” affects comparability
Restructuring charges are often recurring despite being labeled "non-recurring"

examples.title: Basic EPS
examples.problem: Net income = $500,000. Preferred dividends = $50,000. Weighted avg shares = 100,000.

questions.question: Capitalizing an expenditure rather than expensing it will initially:
options: Increase total assets and net income
Have no effect on the balance sheet
questions.explanation: Capitalizing puts the cost on the balance sheet as an asset (higher assets) instead of the income statement (higher income in year 1).

questions.question: Under the treasury stock method for diluted EPS, the number of incremental shares equals:
options: Options exercised minus shares repurchased at market price
Zero if the stock price exceeds the exercise price
questions.explanation: Incremental shares = Options exercised - (Options Ã— Exercise Price / Market Price). Only the NET new shares are dilutive.

questions.question: Revenue = $1M, COGS = $600K, SG&A = $200K. Operating margin is:
questions.explanation: Operating Income = 1M - 600K - 200K = $200K. Operating Margin = 200K/1M = 20%.

questions.question: An analyst should most likely classify a company's recurring restructuring charges as:
questions.explanation: If restructuring charges recur frequently, they should be treated as operating expenses for analysis, despite management labeling them as one-time.

concepts.title: Intangible Assets
concepts.desc: Identifiable (patents, trademarks) can be recognized. Goodwill arises only from acquisitions. Internally generated goodwill NOT recognized.

concepts.title: Goodwill
concepts.desc: Purchase price - Fair value of net identifiable assets. Not amortized but tested annually for impairment. Only written DOWN (GAAP); IFRS similar.

concepts.title: Financial Instruments
concepts.desc: Amortized cost, Fair value through OCI (FVOCI), Fair value through P&L (FVPL). Classification affects income volatility.

concepts.title: Deferred Tax Liabilities/Assets
concepts.desc: DTL: taxable temporary differences (tax owed later). DTA: deductible temporary differences (tax benefit later).

concepts.title: Common-Size Balance Sheet
concepts.desc: Express each item as % of total assets. Shows capital structure and asset composition.

formulas.name: Goodwill
formulas.formula: Goodwill = Purchase Price - FV of Net Identifiable Assets

formulas.name: Current Ratio
formulas.formula: Current Ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities

formulas.name: Debt-to-Equity
formulas.formula: D/E = Total Debt / Total Equity

formulas.name: Debt-to-Assets
formulas.formula: D/A = Total Debt / Total Assets
formulas.where: Proportion of assets financed by debt

decisions.question: FVPL vs FVOCI vs Amortized Cost?
use: FVPL: trading securities, most volatile income
FVOCI: available for sale, unrealized G/L in OCI (not income)
Amortized cost: held-to-maturity debt, most stable income
avoid: Assuming all fair value changes hit net income â€” FVOCI goes through equity

pitfalls: Goodwill is NEVER amortized, only tested for impairment annually
IFRS allows reversal of impairment on most assets; US GAAP does NOT (except held-for-sale)
Deferred tax assets may need a valuation allowance if realization is uncertain
Off-balance-sheet liabilities (operating leases pre-IFRS 16) can hide leverage

questions.question: Goodwill recognized on the balance sheet:
options: Is amortized over its useful life
Is always written up when value increases
questions.explanation: Goodwill is not amortized but is tested at least annually for impairment. It can only be written down, never up.

questions.question: Unrealized gains on FVOCI securities are reported in:
questions.explanation: FVOCI fair value changes bypass the income statement and go directly to OCI (part of shareholders' equity).

questions.question: A deferred tax liability arises when:
options: The company has tax loss carryforwards
The effective tax rate is below the statutory rate
questions.explanation: DTL = taxes will be paid in the future. This happens when accounting income > taxable income (e.g., accelerated depreciation for tax).

modules.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows I

concepts.title: Operating Activities (CFO)
concepts.desc: Cash from core business operations. Start from net income (indirect) or cash receipts (direct). THE most important section.

concepts.title: Investing Activities (CFI)
concepts.desc: Purchases/sales of long-term assets, investments. Negative CFI often signals growth investment.

concepts.title: Financing Activities (CFF)
concepts.desc: Debt issuance/repayment, equity issuance/buyback, dividends. Shows how the company funds itself.

concepts.title: Direct vs Indirect Method
concepts.desc: Direct: shows actual cash receipts/payments. Indirect: starts with NI, adjusts for non-cash items and WC changes. Same CFO result.

concepts.title: Non-Cash Adjustments (Indirect)
concepts.desc: Add back: depreciation, amortization, losses. Subtract: gains. Adjust for WC changes (increase in assets = subtract, increase in liabilities = add).

concepts.title: IFRS vs GAAP Classification
concepts.desc: Interest paid: CFO (GAAP) or CFO/CFF (IFRS). Interest received: CFO (GAAP) or CFO/CFI (IFRS). Dividends paid: CFF (GAAP) or CFO/CFF (IFRS).

formulas.name: CFO (Indirect Method)
formulas.formula: CFO = NI + Non-cash charges + Î”WC
formulas.where: Add depreciation, subtract gains, adjust for changes in current assets/liabilities

formulas.name: WC Adjustment Rule
formulas.formula: Î”Current Asset â†‘ = Subtract from NI; Î”Current Liability â†‘ = Add to NI
formulas.where: Increase in AR means cash not yet collected; increase in AP means cash not yet paid

formulas.name: Total Cash Change
formulas.formula: Î”Cash = CFO + CFI + CFF
formulas.where: Must reconcile to change in cash balance

decisions.question: Direct vs Indirect method?
use: Direct: better for understanding actual cash flows (preferred by IASB)
Indirect: more commonly used, easier to prepare, shows link to NI
avoid: Ignoring the cash flow statement â€” it reveals what the income statement hides

pitfalls: Depreciation is added back NOT because it's a source of cash, but because it reduced NI without using cash
An increase in accounts receivable means revenue was recognized but cash wasn't collected â€” subtract from NI
Interest paid is ALWAYS CFO under US GAAP but can be CFO or CFF under IFRS
Companies can manipulate CFO by stretching payables or accelerating collections

examples.title: Indirect Method Adjustment
examples.problem: NI = $100. Depreciation = $20. AR increased by $15. AP increased by $10. Calculate CFO.
examples.solution: CFO = 100 + 20 (add back dep) - 15 (AR increase = cash not collected) + 10 (AP increase = cash not paid) = $115

questions.question: Under the indirect method, depreciation expense is added to net income because it:
options: Was deducted in computing NI but did not use cash
questions.explanation: Depreciation reduced net income but no cash was spent. Adding it back adjusts NI to reflect actual cash from operations.

questions.question: An increase in accounts receivable is treated as a:
options: Addition to net income in the indirect method
Subtraction from net income in the indirect method
questions.explanation: Higher AR means revenue was booked but cash not collected. Subtract from NI to get actual cash received.

questions.question: Under US GAAP, interest paid is classified as:
questions.explanation: Under US GAAP, interest paid is always CFO. Under IFRS, the company can choose CFO or CFF.

questions.question: A healthy, growing company would most likely have:
options: Positive CFO, negative CFI, negative CFF
Positive CFO, negative CFI, positive CFF
Negative CFO, positive CFI, positive CFF
Positive CFO, positive CFI, negative CFF
questions.explanation: Mature growing companies generate positive operating cash (CFO+), invest in growth (CFI-), and may return cash to shareholders (CFF-).

modules.title: Analyzing Statements of Cash Flows II

concepts.title: Free Cash Flow to Firm (FCFF)
concepts.desc: Cash available to ALL capital providers (debt + equity). FCFF = CFO + Int(1-t) - FCInv.

concepts.title: Free Cash Flow to Equity (FCFE)
concepts.desc: Cash available to equity holders. FCFE = CFO - FCInv + Net borrowing.

concepts.title: Cash Flow Ratios
concepts.desc: Cash flow adequacy, reinvestment, debt coverage, interest coverage from cash flows.

formulas.name: FCFF from CFO
formulas.formula: FCFF = CFO + IntÃ—(1-t) - FCInv

formulas.name: FCFF from NI
formulas.formula: FCFF = NI + Dep + Int(1-t) - FCInv - WCInv

formulas.name: FCFE
formulas.formula: FCFE = CFO - FCInv + Net Borrowing
formulas.where: Cash available to equity after investment and debt

formulas.name: Cash Flow to Revenue
formulas.formula: CF/Revenue = CFO / Net Revenue
formulas.where: Cash-generating ability per dollar of revenue

formulas.name: Debt Coverage Ratio
formulas.formula: Debt Coverage = CFO / Total Debt
formulas.where: Ability to repay debt from operations

decisions.question: FCFF vs FCFE?
use: FCFF: for firm valuation (WACC-based DCF)
FCFE: for equity valuation (cost of equity-based DCF)
avoid: Using FCFE when capital structure is changing significantly â€” use FCFF

pitfalls: FCFF adds back after-tax interest because it's available to debt holders too
FCFE is AFTER debt payments â€” can be negative if firm is borrowing heavily to invest
High net income with low CFO is a red flag for earnings quality

examples.title: FCFF Calculation
examples.problem: CFO = $200M, Interest expense = $30M, Tax rate = 25%, CapEx = $80M. Calculate FCFF.

questions.question: CFO = $150M, Interest = $20M, Tax = 30%, CapEx = $60M. FCFF is closest to:
FCFE differs from FCFF in that FCFE:
options: Is available only to equity holders
Uses cost of debt as discount rate
questions.explanation: FCFE represents cash available to equity holders after debt obligations. FCFF is available to both debt and equity holders.

concepts.title: FIFO
concepts.desc: First In, First Out. Ending inventory reflects recent costs (closer to replacement cost). In rising prices: higher income, higher inventory.

concepts.title: LIFO
concepts.desc: Last In, First Out (US GAAP only). COGS reflects recent costs. In rising prices: lower income (tax savings), lower inventory, better cash flow.

concepts.title: Weighted Average
concepts.desc: Average cost of all units available. Results fall between FIFO and LIFO.

concepts.title: LIFO Reserve
concepts.desc: Difference between LIFO and FIFO inventory values. Disclosed by LIFO companies. Used to convert LIFO to FIFO for comparison.

concepts.title: Inventory Write-Down
concepts.desc: IFRS: lower of cost or NRV (reversals allowed). US GAAP: lower of cost or market (no reversals).

formulas.name: FIFO Inventory from LIFO
formulas.formula: FIFO Inventory = LIFO Inventory + LIFO Reserve
formulas.where: To make LIFO companies comparable to FIFO

formulas.name: FIFO COGS from LIFO
formulas.formula: FIFO COGS = LIFO COGS - Î”LIFO Reserve
formulas.where: Î” = change in LIFO reserve during period

formulas.name: Inventory Turnover
formulas.formula: Inv Turnover = COGS / Average Inventory

formulas.name: Days of Inventory
formulas.formula: DOH = 365 / Inventory Turnover

decisions.question: FIFO vs LIFO in rising prices?
use: FIFO: higher income, higher BS inventory, higher taxes
LIFO: lower income, lower taxes (cash flow benefit), lower BS inventory
avoid: Comparing a LIFO company to a FIFO company without adjusting

pitfalls: LIFO is PROHIBITED under IFRS â€” only US GAAP allows it
In rising prices: FIFO income > LIFO income, but LIFO saves taxes (better cash flow)
LIFO liquidation: if old cheap inventory is sold, income spikes artificially
IFRS allows inventory write-down reversal; US GAAP does NOT

examples.title: LIFO to FIFO Conversion
examples.problem: LIFO inventory = $800K, LIFO reserve = $200K. What is FIFO inventory?
examples.solution: FIFO Inventory = $800K + $200K = $1,000K. The LIFO reserve represents the cumulative difference due to LIFO accounting.

questions.question: In a period of rising prices, compared to FIFO, LIFO will report:
options: Higher net income and higher inventory
Lower net income and lower inventory
Higher net income and lower inventory
Lower net income and higher inventory
questions.explanation: LIFO assigns recent (higher) costs to COGS â†’ lower income. Ending inventory reflects older (lower) costs â†’ lower inventory.

questions.question: LIFO is prohibited under:
questions.explanation: IFRS (IAS 2) does not allow LIFO. Only US GAAP permits LIFO.

questions.question: LIFO inventory = $500K, LIFO reserve = $80K. FIFO inventory would be:
questions.explanation: FIFO Inventory = LIFO Inventory + LIFO Reserve = $500K + $80K = $580K

questions.question: LIFO liquidation occurs when:
options: A company switches from LIFO to FIFO
Inventory quantities decline, causing old (low-cost) layers to be sold
questions.explanation: LIFO liquidation: when quantities sold exceed purchases, older cheaper inventory hits COGS, artificially inflating income.

concepts.title: Depreciation Methods
concepts.desc: Straight-line: equal annual charge. Accelerated (DDB): higher early charges. Units-of-production: based on usage.

concepts.title: Impairment
concepts.desc: When carrying value exceeds recoverable amount. Write down to fair value. IFRS: reversal allowed (except goodwill). US GAAP: no reversal.

concepts.title: Capitalized Interest
concepts.desc: Interest on funds borrowed to construct qualifying assets can be capitalized. Increases asset value, reduces current interest expense.

concepts.title: R&D Costs
concepts.desc: Research: always expensed. Development: IFRS â€” capitalize if criteria met. US GAAP â€” generally expense (except software development costs).

concepts.title: Revaluation Model
concepts.desc: IFRS allows assets to be carried at fair value (upward revaluations to OCI). US GAAP: cost model only (historical cost less depreciation).

formulas.name: Straight-Line Depreciation
formulas.formula: Annual Dep = (Cost - Residual Value) / Useful Life

formulas.name: DDB Depreciation
formulas.formula: Dep = (2 / Useful Life) Ã— Beginning Book Value
formulas.where: Double declining balance â€” ignore residual until final years

formulas.name: Average Age of Assets
formulas.formula: Avg Age = Accumulated Dep / Annual Dep Expense

formulas.name: Remaining Useful Life
formulas.formula: Remaining Life = Net PP&E / Annual Dep Expense

decisions.question: Straight-line vs Accelerated depreciation?
use: SL: when asset provides uniform benefit over life
Accelerated: when asset loses value faster in early years (vehicles, tech)
avoid: Using SL to inflate early-year profits â€” may not reflect economic reality

pitfalls: Capitalizing vs expensing R&D has a BIG impact on income and assets
Impairment is a one-time charge but the loss of value was likely gradual
Average age and remaining life estimates are crude â€” use for trends, not precise values

questions.question: Under IFRS, development costs are:
options: Capitalized if certain criteria are met
questions.explanation: IFRS requires capitalization of development costs when technical feasibility, intent to complete, ability to use/sell, and other criteria are met.

questions.question: Under US GAAP, once an asset is impaired:
options: The impairment can be reversed if conditions improve
The new lower carrying amount becomes the basis and cannot be written up
The asset must be disposed of
questions.explanation: US GAAP prohibits reversal of impairment losses (except for assets held for sale). The written-down value becomes the new cost basis.

questions.question: Asset cost = $100K, residual = $10K, useful life = 5 years. Annual SL depreciation is:

modules.title: Topics in Long-Term Liabilities and Equity

concepts.title: Finance Lease (Lessee)
concepts.desc: Recognize right-of-use asset and lease liability on BS. Depreciate asset, record interest on liability. Front-loaded expense.

concepts.title: Operating Lease (US GAAP)
concepts.desc: US GAAP: right-of-use asset and liability on BS, but single straight-line lease expense. IFRS: treats nearly all leases as finance.

concepts.title: Defined Benefit Pension
concepts.desc: Employer promises specific retirement benefit. Pension obligation and plan assets on BS. Net funded status = Plan assets - PBO.

concepts.title: Share-Based Compensation
concepts.desc: Stock options: fair value at grant date expensed over vesting period. Dilutes EPS. Stock grants vest based on time/performance.

formulas.name: Net Pension Liability
formulas.formula: Net Pension = PBO - Fair Value of Plan Assets

formulas.name: Pension Expense
formulas.formula: Pension Exp = Service Cost + Interest Cost - Expected Return on Plan Assets + Amortization of prior items

decisions.question: Finance vs Operating lease impact?
use: Finance: higher assets/liabilities, higher early expense (front-loaded), EBITDA appears higher
Operating (GAAP): same BS treatment but straight-line expense, lower EBITDA
avoid: Ignoring operating leases in leverage analysis â€” they are real obligations

pitfalls: Under IFRS 16, nearly ALL leases are treated as finance leases for lessees
Finance leases: total expense over lease life = operating lease, but timing differs (front-loaded)
Defined benefit pension assumptions (discount rate, expected return) significantly affect reported results
Higher discount rate â†’ lower PBO â†’ lower pension expense (management discretion)

questions.question: Under IFRS 16, a lessee classifies most leases as:
questions.explanation: IFRS 16 requires lessees to recognize nearly all leases as finance leases (right-of-use asset and lease liability on the balance sheet).

questions.question: Increasing the discount rate used to calculate pension obligations will:
questions.explanation: A higher discount rate reduces the present value of future pension obligations (PBO). This is a common area of management discretion.

questions.question: Stock option compensation expense is recognized:
options: Over the vesting period at fair value as of grant date
questions.explanation: Fair value is measured at grant date and recognized as expense over the vesting period.

concepts.title: Taxable vs Accounting Income
concepts.desc: Accounting income follows GAAP/IFRS; taxable income follows tax law. Differences can be temporary or permanent.

concepts.title: Temporary Differences
concepts.desc: Reverse over time. Taxable temporary diff â†’ DTL. Deductible temporary diff â†’ DTA. Example: accelerated tax depreciation.

concepts.title: Permanent Differences
concepts.desc: Never reverse. Example: tax-exempt income, non-deductible expenses. Cause effective tax rate â‰  statutory rate.

concepts.title: Deferred Tax Asset (DTA)
concepts.desc: Future tax benefit. Arises from deductible temporary differences or tax loss carryforwards. May need valuation allowance.

concepts.title: Deferred Tax Liability (DTL)
concepts.desc: Future tax obligation. Arises from taxable temporary differences. May not reverse if company keeps growing.

concepts.title: Effective Tax Rate
concepts.desc: Tax expense / Pre-tax income. Differs from statutory rate due to permanent differences, tax credits, etc.

formulas.name: Tax Expense
formulas.formula: Tax Expense = Taxes Payable + Î”DTL - Î”DTA

formulas.name: Effective Tax Rate
formulas.formula: ETR = Tax Expense / Pre-tax Income

formulas.name: DTA/DTL
formulas.formula: DT = Temporary Difference Ã— Tax Rate

decisions.question: Will a DTL actually reverse?
use: If company is shrinking: DTL will reverse (tax payment due)
If growing: DTL may never reverse (new DTLs replace old ones)
avoid: Treating all DTLs as true liabilities â€” some effectively behave as equity

pitfalls: Permanent differences do NOT create deferred taxes â€” they affect the effective tax rate
DTA valuation allowance: if realization is doubtful, DTA must be reduced
A change in tax rate requires revaluation of all existing DTAs and DTLs
For analysis, consider whether DTLs will truly reverse or are quasi-permanent

examples.title: Deferred Tax from Depreciation
examples.problem: Book depreciation = $10K, Tax depreciation = $15K, Tax rate = 25%. What deferred tax item is created?
examples.solution: Taxable temporary diff = $15K - $10K = $5K. DTL = $5K Ã— 25% = $1,250. The company paid less tax now but will pay more later.

questions.question: A deferred tax asset is most likely created by:
options: Revenue recognized for tax before accounting
questions.explanation: Tax loss carryforwards create DTAs because they represent future tax savings when the losses are used to offset future taxable income.

questions.question: Permanent differences between taxable and accounting income:
options: Cause the effective tax rate to differ from the statutory rate
questions.explanation: Permanent differences never reverse and do not create deferred taxes. They cause the ETR to differ from the statutory rate.

questions.question: If the tax rate increases, existing deferred tax liabilities will:
questions.explanation: DTL = temporary difference Ã— tax rate. A higher rate means larger future tax payments, so DTLs increase.
